(Laughter) Family Member: I’ll get your time too. Doctor: I’ll leave you guys too. I just wanted to come in and join the party for a minute. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Great. Doctor: But I know there’s more to be discussed. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right now it must be boiling down there. Michigan is pleasant. Patient: Yeah compared to Kentucky, yes. Doctor: So next week I’m thinking if we get you authorized for this Firmagon injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay I can always cancel if I don’t need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we need to uh see if the testosterone is not right then I need… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …to get that authorized. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: If your choice is to have the weight on there or to be a memory I guess I’ll take the weight and work with that. Patient: How have you been? Doctor: Okay. Just running around. Giving more trials and you know keep going. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um I think you know you look great so we need to just come up with… Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: …you know whatever that end date is and it probably should have been your last infusion if we’re gonna.. Patient: It probably will be and I mean I Doctor: Yeah. Patient: think that the decision point, I see him a week from today. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay . Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: But I also would prefer the two of you be the voice, you know. ‘Cuz for me to go over it four different times just because -- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Someone’s not able to get here makes it difficult. Family Member: Right. Patient: Well she has court today. Her ex-husband is – Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general.

Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic. Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case.

Family Member: Can’t be sure? Doctor: Well, let me explore, so I’ve got a couple of threads I’ve got to explore a little more. Patient: Thank you. I appreciate that. Doctor: So let’s uh- Patient: So we’re off the trial now? Doctor: Yeah. We’re off the trial. We’ll probably just want to see a PSA in another month off the testosterone. That may be complicated because you may, because we’re working to go somewhere else so, it may not be that useful for us because it’s not like you’re going to be on- Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know- Doctor: We’ll, we’ll see. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Perfect. Doctor: And so I will be in touch by the end of the week to tell you what I’ve, what I’ve learned. Okay? Patient: Alright. Thank you. Doctor: So just for, for now, Germany, I get what they want, the test results, uh, I’ll see what the policy says about you know just paying for, for the drugs. Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Wow! Small world. Maybe my husband was in training in radiation oncology. Maybe you know him. Family Member: I think so. Doctor: Yeah because (laughs) Patient: Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: You know that was twenty some years ago so that’s probably about right. Family Member: That is. Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, alright, so let me check with D__ if your PSA came back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We are going to do one last ditch effort. I don’t know what’s taking so long even for the labs today. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. It’s almost just like, you know, you stand up and you’re ooh. Not like it’s spinning, but you just don’t have a sense of where you are, and then you right yourself, but, obviously, we don’t want you to fall. Um, so if you start to feel like, you know, there’s some unsteadiness, we need to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a lot of paperwork if you fall. Family Member: Oh, that’s at home. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s still a lot of paperwork if you fall. Just don’t call the clinic. Less paperwork. Yeah. Because then I have to deal with it, and so, yeah, let’s not follow through. Family Member: Less paperwork. Patient: Um. Doctor: Good questions. Man. Patient: Also, some neurologist thing, you know, but, syncope.

Patient: It’s open-ended . I wanted Doctor: There might come a time that we might do something perfectly capable… and at that point Patient: Okay. Perfect. Fine. Doctor: Alrighty. Take this with you. It’s the consent form. The next step on my part would be to contact the study team. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Either he or his scheduling staff. And we’ll be in touch with you by telephone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. in scheduling your appointment and ask you the possible – he maybe to see this Friday. But I think if he can see you this week, than Patient: Okay. Doctor: a lot of information and try to look over that consent form. Patient: I will. Thank you. Doctor: Alright. I like this plan.

Patient: I feel great. Doctor: I was going to say, you look great. I know this is you know waah why can’t we just get this done. But I don’t want to miss anything for you. Patient: Ahhh no I feel great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I have no problems… Doctor: That’s awesome. Patient: …not that I know of. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And then that’s the lung doctor to look up these nodules in your lungs and that’s Dr. S___. And then when you come back it will be March eighth which is time for you next Lupron shot. And we’ll get bloodwork then too to make sure that you’re not rising on that number. Patient: Okay so now I just got to get an appointment today for these? Doctor: Yep when you walk out to where you checked in. Patient: Um hmmm.

Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip? Doctor: Meaning it destroys too much. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else. Family Member: So the pain that he’s having - Doctor: Is in bone. Family Member: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: …and sort of prevent further damage. Patient: Right. Doctor: At least first of all maybe give your nerves a chance to recover at least it prevents total further loss of - Patient: Right. Doctor: -strength and all that. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this what <___> I’m talking about so… Patient: Well I have an appointment with him next week. Doctor: The arms and hands are not something you can… Patient: No, no. Doctor: …get by easily without chuckles]].

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - would be which we thought wasn’t really ethnical Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So I think a lot questions may arise after you look at that. Patient: Okay Doctor: Yeah um I don’t think I’ve given you that consent form. first time you’re seeing it. Patient: Okay.That’s yours Okay and this is Doctor: That is a problem as is the … ORIOLE trial. Patient: Okay. And, this is for me? Doctor: That is your copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: As is this diagram

Patient: I, yeah, I, um, for now on, I’m trying to do them here. I don’t want to --- Doctor: Are we doin’ it on the same day or are you coming in early or? Family Member: We should – they want you to come in early so they can have something – Patient: The appointment for the twenty-fifth, she wanted me to come in a few days earlier. The nurse was saying --- Family Member: A week early. Or Doctor: The same would be true for me in April, if you could do it early? Patient: Yeah, yeah. I will. Doctor: You could do it the same day, but then we don’t – Patient: No, I will. Doctor: But I just have to tell you about aliens, and I’ve got nothing else to talk to you about. Patient: Well, yeah, I know. I’ll get my daughter over here. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: One is going to be for the PSA, one is going to be for the testosterone and another is going to be for the A1C. Patient: Uh hum. I was wondering if we can make it a weekly, a monthly routine of bloodwork like . I’d rather not do that. Doctor: You won’t have monthly from that perspective he or she can Patient: Okay. Doctor: - at least for the short term. If something changes in the future, it might have to be more frequently. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But for now uhm, (keyboarding sounds) Family Member: Eighth. Patient: February eighth, February.. Doctor: Twenty-seventh? Patient: Yeah. (sound of printer operating) Doctor: This is from the week of January eighth, two thousand eighteen. It doesn’t have to be that specific day.

Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this – Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh.

Patient: Are you gonna give me the sixty OxyContin? Doctor: Yeah I gave you. One is sixty and then the Percocet is a… Patient: One hundred twenty? Doctor: One hundred twenty. Patient: Okay, last time you gave me OxyContin, you gave me one hundred twenty. Doctor: I know because that was the short acting. That’s what I’m telling you. The short acting OxyContin you had one hundred twenty. This is the long acting. Healthcare Professional: This is the one you take in the morning and at night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So - that’s why I said if I give you the Percocet it’s going to lower your dose of OxyContin. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: But if that works for you I’m good with that. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

Patient: Okay. I got… Doctor: Okay. Patient: I want to make sure we understand either other. Doctor: Yeah I know. You’re right. Patient: We always understand each other. That’s what I like about my doctor. Patient: When they did the what-ya-call-it survey, Healthcare Professional: Uh huh. Patient: I put high marks because I understand because we trust… Doctor: Well I’m glad you understand because otherwise – otherwise you’re not gonna do what’s good for you. Patient: You’re right and I listen. You listen to me and I… Doctor: You sure do listen. Yeah. Patient: That’s what I like about everything. Doctor: So I’m going to give you three scripts. Okay. One for the sleeping pill.

Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down.

Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter.

Patient: Well, I just work this job. (Laughter) Doctor: The job has exercise? Patient: Oh, my, God. That’s exercise right there, but, uh, you know. Doctor: You’re eating a low, low-fat and high-fiber diet? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So you’re doing all the right things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, uh, we’ll continue to follow you closely, like every six months. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you have any problems before that time, give us a call. Patient: Um hum. Because I don’t feel, I don’t feel sickly or anything like that. You know? Doctor: Alright. That’s good.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know the paperwork that we usually do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The, it, the biggest side effect can be dropping of blood counts. So what you’re gonna have to do… Doctor: No. The best way to prevent it is we will give you a shot the second day, okay, the day after your chemo to um help prevent the blood counts from dropping. Patient: So this will be the last chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For this particular one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then next time we’ll start the new one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay and that will be uh so you’ll have to come two days in a row every three weeks.

Patient: Side effects? Doctor: You could have had the radiation. This is intravenous infusion. You know what this is, is the stuff that Marie Curie discovered all those years ago in the late eighteen hundreds. That’s what she discovered to try to treat cancer and now we actually use to treat cancer. Patient: Oh, wow! Doctor: Yeah. It’s just in smaller doses. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, I think the fact you’ve had radiation before is not, you know, an issue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Where it would have been an issue is if you’d gotten so much that you didn’t have any bone marrow reserve left, you know, like you’re perpetually having a low red blood cell count and need a blood transfusion but that’s not you so it’s something we consider but definitely not something we have to fuss about with you. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Just so you know cost wise, you know, no one ponies up money to just do this because, you know, you’re used to having the high ticket items for Zytiga and Xtandi but this is about fifteen thousand a dose so insurance has to clear it because that’s just the drug cost not everything else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, in that sense you might see a bigger invoice, you know, at the end of it but most insurance companies cover it in whole

Patient: Well yeah, it is. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out. The time will just be when your body poops out and it’s not safe for us to continue. It’s just - Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: - stupid to continue. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because you’re you’re just not going to be able to be strong enough. Other than that - Patient: Yeah. But strong enough now. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: But I mean from a fact that I guess I’m looking for the future Doctor: Of course, Patient: though too and this question that -

Family Member: So he had Patient: For eight years. Family Member: Weird sleep rhythms then. And then he, he did, um, move into a period of time where he worked a more normal, more universal schedule. Yeah and then started this, you know, this investigation thing which is very, sometimes it’s very haphazard. Doctor: Okay. Well, last time you were talking about kidney stone pain and that you felt like you were peeing razor blades. Patient: Yes, none. That had happened, maybe two more pees. (Laughs) Doctor: And, have you been to the hospital? Patient: Mmm, no. Family Member: No. Not since -- Patient: Not since the, the kidney stone prior to the last one. Doctor: Appetite okay? Patient: Oh. Yeah. Comfort, comfort eating has been my, my, uh, default since I was a kid. So. Doctor: Okay, bowels are - weight, uh, any changes?

Patient: Nope. Doctor: Are you circumcised? Patient: Yep. Doctor: And you’re still smoking? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Are you ready to quit? Patient: Nope. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay. And we talked last time about whether you want a call from the quit line to help you quit. The answer’s no because you just told me you don’t want to quit. Patient: No. That’s the least of my trouble. I ain’t going to do it. Doctor: I tell you ever you and I have the same birthday? Patient: Yeah. (Laughs) Doctor: So comes in for follow-up. How have you been?

Patient: What do you mean I won’t be - Healthcare Professional: D____ doesn’t start um - Doctor: Wait, he doesn’t have Healthcare Professional: Yeah, I was going to put a sticker up there. D____ doesn’t start I.V.’s; she can only draw blood. Patient: No? Family Member: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that.

Healthcare Professional: You want to go - Well maybe you should go down there and then you can come back up and get your treatment. Doctor: Yeah, maybe you can go, yeah, okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, that way you don’t miss your appointment down there. Doctor: Yeah that makes sense, while they’re preparing the treatment. Family Member: Right. Patient: I can tell him thanks for buying her a new car. Doctor: He didn’t buy it. Healthcare Professional: She probably bought it (chuckles) Patient: Oh it’s you – it’s your it’s everybodies - it’s both your monies; it’s not just - Doctor: No, no, he is just, yeah. No, but he’s really trying to drive it as much as he can right now. Healthcare Professional: Yours? Doctor: The problem, well the worst thing is my son sent a picture to all of his friends and you know my sister; he sent it to his cousin, my sister’s kids and so they told my sister and I hadn’t had a chance to tell her that I bought this car. And she’s like, “Are you out of your mind? You bought N____ a Mercedes?” (Chuckles)

Patient: So you’re… Family Member: She’s serious. Doctor: No I am, I’m serious. Patient: Wake up, wake up, five more? Doctor: Yeah, total over time, but let’s just do one at a time. Patient: Oh. Doctor: The key is you’re still – you know it’s still shrinking. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Until I get you – you could get five more, but if you beat me by getting your PSA to zero, then I’ll stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: How’s that for a challenge? Family Member: So if it comes back today and it’s zero?

Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: Um and it just depends on where you want to see this person. I’m – Do you see the B______ docs? Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Yep. Are a R____ or T____?

Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: So if the placebo is a non-starter for you, then we skipped that as an option. But again just thinking broad terms first before we get into those details. Just thinking in broad terms so push off the for hormone therapy for a while and do a targeted radiotherapy instead. Or whether you feel that you just want to go ahead and give the hormone therapy to increase the chances of that lasting as long as possible or do some remission that lasts Patient: And yeah, but the way I’m going, I’d be the one in three. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm. Doctor: Alright, and then starting treatment when you just when you develop metastatic disease. Option two is what we call intermittent hormone therapy. So, what this approach means is that you would get hormone therapy, which is the primary treatment for prostate cancer. If you were here in this metastatic bucket, you can get started with hormone therapy. But you would get started on hormone therapy for six months and then we stop and then and that'll bring down your PSA and then we wait until some threshold PSA, your PSA is about 31 now, so we could wait until it gets to 31 again. And sometimes we wait until it’s 10 sometimes 50, but you know, we would, we would only give you the hormone therapy intermittently, so not continuously so you get it for six months, two shots, shot us for three months, lasts for three months. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So you get it for two shots and then you stop. What this medicine does is it makes your testosterone levels go to zero. So it works on your testicles which produce the testosterone and it makes them stop producing testosterone. So people have like menopause type symptoms. Mm? Family Member: So you’re going to use Lupron? Doctor: Yes, exactly. Family Member: Mhm.

So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation?

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I would say I wouldn’t want to look back and not do everything I could have done. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: We might not cure you, but I think psychologically, you know I’ve done everything I can. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: But that you know, people feel differently. The only thing I say is you know to people is you really, really do have to do the radiation and the hormones. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And that’s, and the data is clear. Everything else we’re doing you have to do is you know unmeasurable. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Because if you do the radiation and hormones you have a fifty/fifty shot at being cured. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So if the cancer never comes back you don’t know if what we did helped or not. Right, I admit that.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So there’s two, like I said, two knocks against you that may make, huh, everything that we just talked about, make it so that we’re not able to do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but then we can just, when I see you, plan what day you want to get chemotherapy started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Does that make sense? Patient: Yep. Doctor: And let me see if you’re all set for when your next hormone shot is. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that’s due the last week of, first week of, last week of April. And you’re set for that. You already have that appointment set up, add on because it will be three weeks from now about when we might get started with the chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I refilled the ibuprofen. I sent it to your local pharmacy. Patient: Okay.

Family Member 2: Right, right. Doctor: I mean then I think we should sort of say I don’t care what the PSA is doing but you’re doing great and the scans are looking fine. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We just stay the course. Questions? Family Member: I just have one question. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: So from part one to part two the trial that he was on, Doctor: Mm Hmm Family Member: was there any statistics showing promise from part one to part two or was it…? Doctor: In this particular one? These pills that he’s on? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: The part two hasn’t started yet. So right now he’s is on the phase one but we know what dose to give him so… Family Member: Right, the part two – part one of this phase one series.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. Not in everybody, but usually I see it more in younger guys like you than I do in, you know, much older guys. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, but I think that would be the easiest thing to do. It’s a pill you take every day. I have a range of responses. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Many years ago. Doctor: And because it’s one kidney and you know whether the enzalutamide is doing anything, the protein, the diabetes, the losartan, the hypertension it all (noise) Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …and that’s just way too hard for me to keep up. I can only focus in on your prostate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m now going to send you to the expert. So if it’s not him then somebody else over will be fine. They’re all really good. Patient: Yeah we’ll get - What’s the, what’s the group that he’s in? Doctor: I think it’s really like B______ Nephrology. There’s only one big group there. Family Member: Okay. Patient: M___ Kidney Consultants. Oh, okay. Doctor: Yeah and they may be called that. Yep. Patient: And yeah, yeah that must be because that’s their office in R___ and T___...

Patient: Also, some neurologist thing, you know, but, syncope. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: He told me to start weaning off from the tamoxifen. Patient: And that stuff is nasty to get off from. Doctor: Go slow. Patient: Yeah. That’s right. So I don’t know if that’s going to effect- Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. During the- this is different than the Lupron and that right? Isn’t this usually used for gastric? Doctor: It’s all, yeah, but there’s a lot of information for earlier states like now. So it’s also been given in men right before their surgery stages. We know that the cancer cells are dying in the actual prostate. So it’s been given in every possible place, but the FDA approval is when you’re castrate resistant. Yeah. Patient: Okay. That’s what I read. Doctor: I know. Man. What happened here? Did you teach him stuff? Family Member: I didn’t, actually.

Patient: Right. No. Doctor: No, no, no, right, because you don’t know how you’re going to react. Most people just get sleepy and want to take a nap and then they feel better but everyone’s different. Okay? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Make a copy of this and then. Oh yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Is Provenge off the table? Doctor: Provenge is off the table in the sense that your PSA is um too high I think but more importantly that you have pain. You know, Provenge is good with, it’s kind of like your asymptomatic, you’re doing great, you have a couple spots, your PSA is less than thirty. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know, that’s not you and it kind of, you know, we were hoping with a little bit more time away from the Xtandi that that would have been you Patient: Right. Doctor: but that’s not the way you’re declaring yourself so, no, it won’t help. Patient: Okay. That’s no problem. Doctor: Yeah, we just need to move on to something a little bit more powerful. That is powerful in the right setting. You know, kind of like you’re almost like you have the flu and then I come around hey, did you want that flu shot, I’m kind of in the middle of it so no point whereas if this was a few months ago and it’s before flu season then it’s hey, it’s time for the flu shot. Okay, I’ll get it before I’m actually having the flu and the symptoms. Patient: That reminds me of another question.

Family Member: APS. Patient: She came here actually for one of the world experts on APS. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Which is a blood disorder. Clotting. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: I thought I would mention it ‘cuz I think for her – Doctor: I don’t know enough about that. I’d have to read up about that, but I don’t think it relates. Family Member: For her, it was a really easy fix. Doctor: That’s not a gene on this panel that they did for you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They do more common cancer genes. Family Member: Oh, I see.

Patient: R____. Family Member: R____. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Preferably B______ in uh W____ even. Doctor: So there’s a large nephrology practice at B______. And they’re scattered everywhere. Patient: Right. Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Um but you know this is one guy who I really know him well ‘cause he took care of my dad so his group is very good and there’s like a gazillion of them, but they’re all good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But you actually need I think at this stage of the game from an honest to goodness nephrologist to really manage this part. Patient: I had one several years ago. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And it cannot substitute as a weight loss plan. Doctor: Let me just say it for the record. Patient: Well, yeah. We’re working on that part of it. Family Member: Yes. We are.

Patient: Then I got a, then I got Doctor: Then, you got to try it. I don’t see you using it. Patient: I got it down ‘cuz it don’t, it don’t really be working for me. You know what I’m sayin’? ‘Cuz all I do is when I stop, I lean on it, lean down on it. I’d settle for the one with the seat on it. Now see, that’s the one that, um, I gotta see, if, if you can, can you see when the next time I can get one? The one with the seat on it? Doctor: The walker with the seat? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’ll give you script for that to take… Patient: Now see, I have, I have to, I have to always sit, I have to always sit down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know, because I be fatigued. Doctor: I see. Not a problem. Patient: You know what I’m saying? And, that, that’s the only problem (XXX) Doctor: I’ll give you a script take it over to Vincent’s or whatever and see what they say.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we tend to treat it systemically. Patient: Okay. Doctor: …with pills or IV or whatnot which we’ll talk about. So I don’t want to cut you open, but I do want to re-biopsy you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and I talked to our radiologist. He’s gonna see at the time that you’re on the table of the CAT scan what is the best area to target because these things all move as well. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Preferably the largest one because it’s an easier target, but we want to make sure that one, it’s safe for you. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, that we can get enough samples. So here the ‘enough’ means that we’d like to get some stuff for testing? Patient: Right. Doctor: Just regular hey what’s on the pathology? Patient: Mhmm.

Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: If I need it. Doctor: A baby aspirin once a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Atorvastatin forty milligrams once a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You’re on the bicalutamide? That’s the medicine for your prostate cancer? Family Member: He took him off of that. Patient: I was ready to say that. Doctor: Your Colace or the docusate to help soften your stools? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Folic acid one milligram pill a day? Patient: Yes.

Patient: Well, I have some relatives in Germany. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And, uh- Family Member: Yeah. If they’re still there. (Laughter) Patient: Pardon? Family Member: I said if they’re still there because-. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. That’s a good point. Right. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, I think if you want to explore that, my feeling would be if you can get it on the study, well and good. If not, you should explore if you can go and, you know, I don’t know what it costs there, and, you know, what you have to pay. Family Member: If you can get on, on the study, which would involve the scan, doing the scan? Doctor: Doing the scan first. Family Member: Yeah. Of course. Doctor: But even there, they would do the scan first, because if it’s not going to help you, they’re not going to push you to get the treatment that’s not going to work.

Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: And have you been able to-? Any of these things come out to you? Have you already seen these labs or everything I’m going to tell you is new? Patient: You going to tell me new. Doctor: Let me see what I have. You had your bloodwork yesterday. So your white count’s normal. Huh, you’re anemic, been about the same. You’ve got normal platelets. So your iron stuff isn’t really helping, but, huh, your kidney test, liver tests, your potassium is on the low side so you take your supplement. You probably often forget one of them, one of them probably, I bet. Doctor: It’s hard to remember that second one. Blood sugar’s okay. One of your bone tests is still high, but not as high as it was last time. That doesn’t mean we’re going to do anything different. But, huh, and then your liver tests, kidney tests are normal. Huh, your testosterone says you have no testosterone. So the medicines we’ve been giving you are doing their job. Then your PSA has changed. Huh, it was twenty three months ago, twenty-eight when I saw you four weeks ago, and now it’s thirty-nine. Let’s see what we have for scans. I’ll look at your brain. Your brain looks fine. Now to this MRI. Really they don’t talk much about your bones. That’s good. Huh, let’s see. Your bone scan. Huh, did we have that last time as well? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So again, you’ve got the multiple sites of cancer in your bones, and you’ve got swollen glands down in your pelvis, don’t look like they’re from your cancer. Huh, let me see what I told you last time so that I am consistent. Okay. So what questions do you have for me? Patient: Huh, only one, I mean, huh, what are we going to do about this pain I’m feeling? Are we going to do what we’re doing? What we’ve been doing? Doctor: Yeah. I, I’m, I’m thinking we need to change. Huh, you know, get you off these pills and maybe go to chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, chemotherapy’s got about a one in two chance of helping the pain. Huh, we could always radiate your bones if the pain doesn’t get better with the chemo. Huh, but I’d like to give you something that goes everywhere the cancer cells are, huh, so that, huh, huh, it’s a different approach than what we’ve done. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___? Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play.

Family Member: Period. Doctor: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s… Family Member: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures Doctor: A fracture now would really set us back. So- Family Member: Yes because we have brittle bones. Doctor: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often. Family Member: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -and keep him from harm. Doctor: Yep. Family Member: Because we’re doing Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: a little bit better

Family Member: To the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s right. See? You’re everywhere. You’re taking trips you don’t even know you’re taking trips. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Patient: I’m tiring myself out. Family Member: a problem that we’re going out of town? Doctor: When are you going? Family Member: Saturday. Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: No. We won’t, I mean, with the holidays, you know, nothing happens. It’s almost like a, not a for sure. Next week it’s a shutdown, but a lot of places are still not functional- Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Family Member: Right, the part two – part one of this phase one series. Doctor: Oh I see okay got it. So it’s the dose expansion. Yeah so far there are some people who have benefited and been on it for quite a while. So there is some preliminary evidence of his Family Member: Just not a lot of data. Doctor: Yeah but it’s not – the numbers are not that big to really say statistics. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I would say probably two or three people out of the ten, but some of them haven’t even had their first scan yet. So it’s a work in progress. Family Member: Sure. Uh is there any data on uh chemotherapy? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Chemotherapy is standard and approved. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. So its the PSA effect is frequently treatment dependent. Okay so chemotherapy or XTANDI for that matter we know it makes the PSA go down if it’s working. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But not so for Xofigo and for this new medication honestly we don’t know enough- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah, yeah you’re the man but you have more grey. <____> refer me to you. Doctor: I hope that when I see you next time I will be able to give you news that yes he’s coming. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so, so we do this blood test all the way up until September. Doctor: Oh we’re still gonna do the blood test. I still get blood tests. Patient: Huh. Doctor: I still get my blood test. Patient: Oh okay you still uh? How many times? Doctor: Once a year now. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So in twenty years it’s probably gonna be time for me to stop, but we check your blood, we’ll be checking blood for a long time.
PAT So, so, so after um after September and you know everything keeps going… We’ll do it every six months.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s folks who have like not so much hair at this age who just easily lose it. You have a lot of hair. Patient: Yes. When I was on the uh Cometriq. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It started a little thinning but it was turning white. Doctor: Yeah. Um hum. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Patient: And then we adjusted the dose and it started coming. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I had to straighten this way.

Patient: Hum. Doctor: That wasn’t big before, what we’ve got there. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: So we’re going to meet again after so we all describe the tests together so that you know what it is like. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Essentially again with the shot and stuff, it didn’t change. Doctor: Exactly. No. You’re great. You had the last shot June sixth. You’re fine with that. So we’re going to extend it a week or two. Patient: Going to the bathroom. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. You’re eating fine. Patient: I’m eating fine. I’m eating good. Patient: I’m going to eat right now. Doctor: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch?

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer. Family Member: Mm, hmn. Doctor: But that would be potentially something you could participate in. Right now I would be a little bit worried about putting you on it with these gasping things that I can’t explain- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because it might affect our ability to get the therapy in. Uhm, we have another study which I, uh - Transformer - we have a first-in-human study of a drug that comes from plum seeds. In laboratory studies it looks like it can attack and kill prostate cancer cells. So this is a study where we’re looking at a drug that now is in I.V. form to see how often does it affect the PSA, how often do you get side effects that we can’t give it to you. So it’s more about the side effects and whether it helps you or not. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Some of the data says that it could help you, but we don’t know. We’ve never given it to enough men. We treat a number of men and if they do okay, then we go to a higher dose.

Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get -- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Four hundred cubic centimeters or better, Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: but not greater than six hundred. Doctor: Okay good. Family Member: And we … Doctor: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know Family Member: Okay. Doctor: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Not yet, no. Yes, I saw her, but I haven’t talked with her. Doctor: Okay, blood pressure’s high today. What’s that about? Patient: I think rushing here. I hope. Doctor: Any new, new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: Still taking adult aspirin twice a day. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, lovastatin forty milligrams a day Patient: Mm, hmm Doctor: The probiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Your calcium with vitamin D one a day?

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven. Three plus four is seven or equals seven. Those two um numbers are different depending Gleason if

Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’? Doctor: No!!!! What is your fixation about the lower body parts? (Laughs) Patient: Well then – when you go -- how you gonna get to – how you gonna do the biopsy? You gonna cut me open? Doctor: No! You lay down on the CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They numb up an area right around here or here – Patient: Right. Doctor: Depending on what side. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put a needle through – Patient: Yeah.
