Patient: Cancer. The cancer subsided or it can't reverse cancer get worse. Doctor: The cancer has gotten worse and moved on to new spots or new areas. Oh, you know, it's not gonna be shy. It'll tell us. Yeah. So at this moment is just sort of the slow creep, you know, it’s the- What do you mean? It's six right? I mean, you haven't way in the beginning you were near 300 there but you've always been super low. So when we look at you, it's like this tiny little rises but nothing that's like this. Yeah, Patient: Just a quick note- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - it started out much higher than that. I think you get Doctor: Yeah, no, no, I had you correct. Yeah, we met each other after your stuff started but in our system, that's as high as you been? Patient: Yeah.This may not be a question for you. But if I were to retire- Doctor: Mhm. Patient: I'm not sure. I'm not sure what kind of health care insurance I'm gonna have. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Patient: Yeah, but, is so I don't know have you- I don’t know how to ask the question. So is there assistance available? If I would need it if I changed to a different insurance. Doctor: You mean as per trial or in general

Family Member: You went out on the deck. Patient: No. I’m talking about walking. I’m not talking about that now. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Right. I just wanted to clarify. Patient: But I went out to, uh, to see how, how to walk because sometimes it was difficult walking especially with this leg here. And, uh, I don’t, I don’t know, I had a whole lot of pep in my step- Doctor: Okay. Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.

Patient: I thought you said the scans didn’t… Family Member: That’s what you said last month. Healthcare Professional: Last time they had the prelim report, but… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So one of the areas and again like I said I don’t know what to make of this because it is on the bone scan. I thought I – did we talk about this? Okay. Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh) Doctor: So I still think they are because, but what this says is that there is increasing uptake. So since I’m gonna give you these… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: …I wanted you to know. Unfortunately the size are the how bright it is. So increasing uptake means it’s brighter now than it was before. Patient: This is in the bones? Doctor: Correct, yeah. That grade of brightness I guess, doesn’t mean a whole lot for prostate cancer on the bone scan. Okay because even healing bone can look brighter than the other. So on the bone scan really what would tell me that there is progression of the disease would be if there were new areas and there were not. Okay? But I just needed to explain this because- Family Member: Yes.

Patient: All of it. Doctor: And, so you didn’t get any kind of call from the company that did the test? Patient: No. Doctor: As far as you know? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But –

Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And so those are all issues that you’ve got to sort out. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: How do you know it’s working? Family Member: I think that we should probably wait until catheter is out. Patient: Right, that’s what I was thinking originally, Family Member: And see what happens with medication. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um, now about the uh hormone shots. So he’s covered for three months. After that expires he should get another shot and you start chemo? Doctor: He will have another shot, so it should be in here already. I will put it in. Family Member: In January.

Family Member: We’re done. Doctor: Oh yes, I’m just checking. And how is it? Do you love it? Family Member: Yeah, it’s uh; we have to make some changes but yeah, it feels like home. Doctor: That’s awesome, no ladders for you, right? Family Member: I had to argue with him about it. Patient: Could I give away all my ladders? Doctor: Did you put it in the garage sale? I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder. Patient: So what makes you think I may have fallen again? Doctor: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did. Patient: Oh. Doctor: But it might have been last time. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Well you took me off of this thing… Doctor: Yes, yes. Family Member: Yes. That’s the other question. Patient: So… Doctor: So we’re gonna try to put you back on. Patient: Okay, that’s fine… Doctor: ‘Cause I don’t think it’s related… Patient: Right. Doctor: …however all these other doctor’s appointments all gotta go right according to plan… Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …so that we don’t make you worse because there’s still no matter what some clearance of you know, any of the medicines are always somewhat cleared, some percentage by the kidneys so… Patient: Right I understand that.

Family Member: Do you have the results of today’s draw, blood draw? Doctor: I was told that he did not have blood drawn. Did he have it? Family Member: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. No. I don’t, then. I’ll, uh, check. I’ll bring you the results. I don’t think I have a PSA back. Family Member: Oh. Right. Doctor: But, uh- Patient: So what, what involves, getting a shot every month or so? Doctor: Every six weeks, if you go on it. Patient: Every six weeks? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Hum. Well, what happens if I wanted to go to England and get it or Germany? Doctor: You’re a free man. You can go any time.

Patient: When do you, when do you wanna start the trial? Doctor: You already got your scan. We start the biopsy. We go. No, no time wasted. Patient: Well I got – I got to do the biopsy? Doctor: Yes! Patient: What the hell, doc? Doctor: Don’t look at me! It’s science! You’re contributing! Patient: You gonna put me to sleep or what? Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. You’ll be fine. Patient: Oh, man! No!!! Doc! C’mon! Doctor: You’ll be fine! Family Member: Seriously? Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’?

Patient: I’m gonna have to, you know? I’m - Doctor: Do you have the latest list? Did you give it to K____ or is it the same list from before? Patient: Same as before. Doctor: Same as before. Okay. Patient: Yeah. We’re all good. || Good seeing ya. Doctor: Good seeing you too. Alright I will have - Patient: Congratulations on your cert. Doctor: Thank you. I’ll have M____ come in in just a sec. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Alright.

Patient: I do want a life you know I want someone with me you know. Doctor: I hear ya, okay. Patient: So I play dodge ball. (Laughs) Doctor: You’re not the only person. Patient: Yeah. (Laughs) Doctor: That’s like that, anyway. How’s the water passing? Patient: Oh, oh shoot. Oh I use the restroom. You know I control everything. Doctor: You’ve got good control and it comes out in a good stream? Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: No burning? No blood? Patient: Uh mmm. Doctor: Okay that’s good.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: so I want to share it with you guys. Other than that, this is not like chemo. This is not like anything else. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: So the tiredness is the top three that really will be wiping you out. Sometimes it makes you feel so wiped out… Patient: Wait a minute, W__ I got a compliment for you Healthcare Professional: Uh, huh? Patient: Doctor- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -hold on for one second. Doctor: Oh, okay. Healthcare Professional: Uh,huh. Patient: So you said, you said well I know you got the six hundred Motrin, you got eight hundred Motrin, but then we had the morphine and all that other stuff.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Family Member: We was, uh, kind of like laughing come down here to Baltimore. We were like, Baltimore’s not too far from South Africa with the living conditions. You know? Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: so at this moment. One, stop Xtandi; two, we’re going to give you some Xofigo paperwork and you’re going to do some of the – just give him some of the - Healthcare Professional: Lupron. Doctor: Lupron. And then we’ll send you on to see Dr. ___ for a consult. All of that is not a huge rush, but we’re just gonna move it along. Family Member: Yeah, because we’re leaving February fifth, so. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So. Patient: So you don’t want me to take Xtandi at all anymore? Healthcare Professional: No, stop it. Family Member: Can we donate it to somebody that needs it? Healthcare Professional: Yeah, bring it back in. Doctor: Bring it back to us and we’ll make sure it gets recycled to the next person, absolutely. Family Member: To the next person who needs it.

Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A month ago, you hadn’t and now you’ve you’ve crossed that number which I think was twenty-six point seven. So you’re two points above that. The second reason is um having to do with your scans. We have the results of your bone scan and your um CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The um the bone scan looks completely unchanged, in other words normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t think there is any evidence or hint that there could be prostate cancer in the bone. And that is really the most important thing; so I wanted to say that first. The second one is the CAT scan. So on the CAT scan, you have a lymph node inside your abdomen - Patient: Okay.

Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check. Patient: What kind of pills? Doctor: So these are FDA-approved pills called Xtandi, which is the trade name. Uh, they’re four pills once a day, and their primary goal of how they work is it’s, it’s like a big hormone pill again. So it’s to help your shot work better. It also is approved by the FDA because it helps you live longer. No cures. Same as we were before but we need to get a handle on all these things in the lung. In the same way, you’re also a candidate for chemo to tell you the truth. Uh, so chemo’s in the mix as well, but the majority of folks I think, and I’m not saying you do, but my patients tend to prefer pills before going on to chemotherapy, and I think way back when we initially again reconnected you were not in so much favor of chemo, uh, as he’s already shaking his head, but I want to bring that up again because at some point we may need to go to chemo. So I want to put that out there still. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but we do have a set of pills. Now, the good news is every time there’s an approved medication, you know, we’re at K______, so we do a lot of clinical studies. So one of our studies is to use that same medication and see if we add a second pill to half the group whether you’d respond better. So I like that study because it’s all pills and no one gets a placebo when you’re thinking about the Xtandi pills. Everyone is on the regular pill that is approved. The question of the placebo versus the other drug is extra. Okay? So I’m not sure if that makes sense or if you’ve got questions with that, but we’re going to try hard to have you be, you know, considered for that study. Uh, I want you to still recover well from your, your hospitalization, but, uh, but that’s in the works for us to consider. The other part is either way, however we move forward, there’s another study, which is a registry study, called, Iron Man. Uh, not that you become iron man- Patient: Hum. Doctor: but that all your experiences as to what’s happened to you get captured. And that means you write out and answer questionnaires. I write out and answer questionnaires. Uh, and then about once a year we take some blood to see what’s happening uh in terms of new research. Uh, and that participation’s pretty cool because a lot of other men around the world are, are participating. And so we get answers from guys from Australia, Ireland, uh, you know, England uh, gosh, Canada, France, so all of that. So everyone’s experience will be captured. And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger.

Patient: I ain’t been doing too bad, I ain’t been doing too good. Doctor: Okay. So I heard the hip is still hurting? Patient: Yes indeed. Doctor: And is there any other new areas? Patient: No but you know but she was asking me you know like if I’m laying down gets up you know I go it just so happened that I can be around while I’m (pinching) Doctor: Wow. Patient: You know to let my – Doctor: What is his hemoglobin? Healthcare Professional: Eighty, his blood pressure is (XXX) Patient: uh once my blood uh once my blood starts circulating then I’m fine. Doctor: So you have to take it slow. Get up very slowly. Patient: My son, my son he helps me out a lot. Doctor: Okay, good.

Patient: From Dubai to South Africa was nine hours. Doctor: How far to Dubai? It’s like twelve hours? Patient: Oh, man, it was about fourteen, sixteen hours. Doctor: Man, you guys are- Doctor: You had to travel. Doctor: Yeah. They do like the circle route, I guess. Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Patient: Right. Oh. Doctor: Because I don’t quite understand it. Patient: I didn’t know that.

Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent. Patient: Right. Doctor: Then the other twenty percent depending on sort of other plans you might have, you’ll probably end up spending about five thousand dollars. Huh, then you’ll go into the donut and then you don’t have to pay the rest of that. Patient: Well, they said the, huh, supplement plan that I’ve got now, I shouldn’t have to pay nothing out of pocket. Family Member: For normal trials. Patient: For normal things. Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Kind of like we started with this one. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because the first couple of weeks I came down here… Doctor: It was more intense and then it… Family Member: In the beginning. Doctor: And then it smooths off once. Patient: Well okay so you’re talking three different options. Doctor: Yeah basically. Patient: Which one, which one I guess was your recommendation? Doctor: What I was going to propose is that we do things in parallel. Okay? I was going to sort of leave the chemotherapy as a last possible option only because you have it available at any time. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can go to it if none of these work or even after they work and then stop working after sometime.

Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: What’s your name? Family Member: K___ P____. He probably wouldn’t remember me. Doctor: I don’t know, he sometimes tends to remember a lot of the people he did… Family Member: Is he still in radiation oncology here? Doctor: He is. He just started back here within the last year. Before that he was at other hospitals. Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: So yeah. Family Member: That’s great. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: Thank you, thank you again. Doctor: That is amazing. Small world right. Family Member: Yeah. (Laughs)

Patient: Yes. Doctor: The gabapentin three hundred milligrams three times a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So lidocaine patch. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Patches twice a day? Once a day? Patient: Maybe twice a day. Doctor: Okay. The Lisinopril five milligrams once a day? Patient: Um hum. Yeah. Doctor: Melatonin. You take two tablets at night for insomnia? Family Member: Actually, that’s- Patient: No. Not every day. Doctor: Metoprolol twenty-five milligrams?

Patient: I wasn’t aware of- Doctor: Like. No. I think it’s okay. I think K___ has everything. So we’re good. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. I just want to double check. You scared the heck out of me last time. So I’m just gonna I don’t know keep an eye on you just a little bit closer - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: -until I’m confident that I can let you go for three months. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. It’s all good. Don’t run away. I’ll bring back K___ and the nutrition book. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m not exactly sure when that will happen. But it accelerates and that happens sooner. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace you know if it increases by one or two decimal points, who knows, it may take you know six to nine months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Maybe up to twelve months. So one of the things that I wanted to discuss with both of you today is what we would do if it reached one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - whether bone scan or CAT scan? Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Or is it still invisible and can we not see it? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: They’re just taking it as uh pay as you go. Uh so we’ve talked before, and I know you have the means to do it. Uh they, so, I’d, I’d work with a group. There’s a group in Heidelberg, Germany, and there’s a group in a place called Bad Berka, which is, I could show it to you on a map, but it’s, it’s outside of Frankfurt. Patient: Um huh.. Doctor: It’s near, it’s in East Germany. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh those two groups have the biggest experience. The guy I know very well is in Bad Berka. Uh I think both groups though will take referrals, and then they take over and make the arrangements for folks to come, put you up, all the things. And the number they quoted me is about fifty-thousand bucks to do it. Um which by American standards, is incredibly cheap, but because you can’t get, take advantage of health insurance, you know. Patient: Yeah. It really is sort of out of pocket. Family Member: But he could do it right away? Doctor: He could potentially. I, I, at least I could contact my contact and find out. I also know the group in Heidelberg. We could find out. Uh the groups here, uh I don’t know the Cornell group and the group at UCLA. I don’t know. Those are trials. So they’re going to have eligibility. Patient: Do you think I’d be eligible for them? Doctor: I don’t know. I, I can look into it. Patient: Yeah. I -

Patient: Oh the shoulders are good. Doctor: Okay what is…? Patient: I don’t have any you know… Doctor: Is this ten mg? Patient: Five in the morning, five at night. Doctor: Okay did it flare up after the treatment last time? Family Member: No. Patient: No. Doctor: You didn’t notice any different? Doctor: Okay so should we try going to five once a day or you don’t want to rock the boat? Patient: I suppose we could try it and see what happens. Doctor: We’re gonna try it. Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next.

Patient: Oh yeah but anyway, but anyway uh Dr. B____ the, the, the I think he’s short. I can’t think of his name. Anyway, he told me to talk to him. It’s a Chinese guy that that that denied me, but his boss… Doctor: M____ Pharmacy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or where? Patient: His boss is the short guy. That’s who I’m waiting to talk to. I’m hoping he’ll be here today so that when I leave here today I can talk to him. Doctor: Okay. So we’ll give you the script and then you go there first see if they are willing to. Patient: Tell me what’s going on Dr. B____. That’s what I want to know. What is the – this is the call they’re sending everything Doctor: Let me take a look. Patient: So everything I’m going through man seems like it’s causing this man I mean when they said pain… Doctor: Okay so I looked at. Patient: …when they say pain I’m saying like… Doctor: Okay can I see it? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s not bad. There’s nothing wrong with ya. You know, if you’re achy- Patient: Just tired. Doctor: Just ‘cuz, you know, you’re just take a couple of Advil, and you just say, “I, I gotta go take a nap.” Most people don’t notice much. Uh, just like, “Okay, they told me I’d feel it this weekend.” Uh. Family Member: Okay! Doctor: Most people really just lose the end of their day. You know, they’re at work, work, work, and they just sorta say, “Oh.” And they’re toast. Patient: And when the end of the day is all over, you nap. Doctor: Mm, hmm. But it sounds like you’re pretty good about sorta if I have to take a nap today, I will or if I - Patient: Oh yeah, if I know I gotta work late, I nap now and stay up late later, and sleep when I can ‘cuz I’m having some days with no troubles. It’s Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so those orders are out. So, you’re going to the purple wall. Swipe your card. And they will sorta set up the follow-up visits, and then they can take you upstairs. You’ll go onto the second floor and swipe your card again, and that will tell them that you’re here for your flu shot. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh. Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. Hhh (chuckles) Family Member: So, until Doctor: So, I’ll, I’ll start that. You’re gonna need to sign a permission and all that with T_. Healthcare Professional: Yep.

Healthcare Professional: They are moving. Doctor: Yes. Healthcare Professional: That one moved that way. Doctor: So just uh can you put us on mute a minute? Thank you. Patient: Pardon? Doctor: Does your ex know? Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: Okay. You know well when you’re on chemo she’s going to know, so. Patient: Yeah. Uh, I really hate the idea of losing my hair. Doctor: You’ll probably just get thinning. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you have a lot of hair.

Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then at the end of the day you look at the outcomes and you see are the recurrence rates you know slowed down less in the patients that receive the Metformin or alternatively our prevention rates that with time those that don’t receive the Metformin. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes.

Patient: I think that’s probably his standard of care that he has to follow up, but if you’re following up - Doctor: Well, I would keep the appointment with him in January. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, maybe after that I could see you in April and if it turns out in January, your PSA has, you know, gone - instead of continuing to go south, it’s gone north, or we may, we may need to switch treatments whatever, then I would, I would maybe see you sooner to discuss that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, I, why don’t I - I’m going to make the appointment, I think, part of this appointment this January and, uh, I’m not sure if he’s doing the six-month injection, but, um, I’ll make an appointment for, it’s says April sixteenth. I’ll just make it April seventeenth which is a Tuesday. And, you don’t have to see him; you just see me. Family Member: Not the sixteenth? Doctor: I’ll e-mail him, but you can also tell him at the next appointment. Patient: I will. Doctor: You think it’s best – does he think it’s a good idea? He and I do this all the time. We, we transition after he’s finished with the radiation part. Because, unless - I mean, he’s not going away. We might need him again. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Down the road maybe. I don’t know. I hope not. But, but, but I think in terms of talking about the next trials, all those kinds of things, you need to be with, you’re going to, that’s going to be me. Okay?

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it?

Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Because I know you’ll never call me if you’re getting sick from the medicine. Patient: Oh! I’ll call! Doctor: No, you won’t! Patient: Yeah. I’ll call. Well, like I said, I started getting that pain in my hip last week, but I knew I was coming here today to see you, and I said I’ll just wait until I go in. But, yeah, it was getting kind of, it was startin’ to hurt. Doctor: Getting tough. Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, even though some of these things sound cool, I don’t really have a good sense of, you know. So I’d, I’d like to choose either a trial with a hormone drug or just do the hormone drug, uh, as the next step. Patient: Are you satisfied with that we go to? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: I am if you are too?. Family Member: Do you want to do the one, have him go to that one that has, uh, Xtandi and the other one that-? Doctor: The Zytiga or the, no, you mean the trial? Family Member: The trial, yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. I’ll, I’ll clarify that today. Okay? As soon as we’re done. Uh, there’s two different groups I’ve got to talk to, uh, about that. Uh, then I will, uh, I’ll get that information to you as soon as I have it. And if I don’t- Family Member: But one, one of them you said that he’d get both drugs. So he’d probably want to do that one, I guess. Because one you get one and the other one you’re going to get both. You just get the- Patient: You talking about the one with the prednisone? Family Member: No.

Patient: I don’t think I’d have any trouble tolerating. Doctor: Yeah. It doesn’t seem like, from everything I’m gathering about this medication, it seems like it’s been easy to tolerate. There may be some infusion reaction or, you know-. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Some occasional side effects, but we’ll be monitoring your blood labs, liver function, kidney function, all of that, every time before we give you that injection. Family Member: So- Doctor: So you’ll be monitored. Patient: So when I do get, when do I get my tickets? Doctor: Well, once, first, you have to sign the consent and do all the screening. Then we can register you and start booking the, the tickets, and whatnot. Patient: Here’s the papers I sign? Doctor: This is not the paper. Doctor: We have to bring you- Family Member: He didn’t care.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth. Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks.

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Have fun. Enjoy the weather. Patient: Let’s see. Six weeks is going to put us in middle of July? Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: End of July. Family Member: So what is – can he take anything to help him sleep? Like natural? Doctor: You can try melatonin. Family Member: Melatonin. That’s right. Doctor: I suggest stop drinking at seven p.m. and you’ll be a miracle. You won’t even get up that much. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’ll say, oh, my, gosh, I’m awake and I didn’t get up.

Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to.

Doctor: Thank goodness. Doctor: hhh Now, that is something. Even though, I yell at you sometimes. Patient: Right. Noooo, I’ve got, Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve got a lot of respect for you. Doctor: Thank you. Sit up for a minute. Let me, uh, put down. (Paper rattling) Patient: Mmm.hmmm. Doctor: Does that hurt? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay, how far can you bring it? (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: No? How about the other side? (Pause) Patient: That’s fine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay you’re not going over to the infusion today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh we’ll go from there. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Now prescription wise do you need anything? Patient: No. Doctor: You’re all set. Patient: That prednisone that you gave me I think like four or five refill left on it so I’ve got plenty. Doctor: And are you using Norco or anything at all? Patient: Ah no I’ve been taking – what I’ve been taking a little bit for pain is… Family Member: Ibuprofen. Patient: I got some two hundred milligram Ibuprofen. I’ve been taking two of those, so about four hundred…

Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer.

Family Member: And is that for all chemotherapy or just this specific one that T___ has? Doctor: The neuropathies, the eye tearing are pretty specific to this drug. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the rest of it because we’re killing dividing cells, Family Member: Uh hum. the hair loss, the drops in blood count are consistent with chemotherapy. Doctor: Yeah, we do, you know we know what we need to give you to sort of prevent the nausea when you’re getting the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then something like the Zofran or Ondansetron that you have at home is what we use in the middle of the week if you had nausea after the chemo. Family Member: Mm. Tiredness was my biggest obstacle. Doctor: Tired is definitely. Family Member: Fatigue was unbelievable. So have you decided? Patient: Too early to decide.

Patient: Are you smoking? Come on. Family Member: Whoa wait a minute. Patient: There’s a disconnect you change your… Family Member: Did you see my face? Patient: Probably mine too but uh – but who did we hear routine would be six? Who told us six? Family Member: I don’t know… Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total.

Patient: ‘Oh okay. You got a strong stomach?’ I said ‘yeah.’ He said ‘look here come over here.’ Doctor: Oh he showed it to you? Patient: Showed it to me. Doctor: Oh my goodness. Patient: Showed it to me. Electric knife, self-cauterizing… Doctor: Oh this is like (pfft) Patient: I’m so - I’ve seen it. I’ve seen it… Doctor: Okay. Yeah, this’ll be… Patient: …and I’ve had it so if that makes more sense for you… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …go for it. Doctor: Thank you. I think you know when you have stuff in the in the belly though we don’t like to open you up unless we have to. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Chloraseptic. Doctor: That might help. Or when you’re at the drugstore picking up your ibuprofen, there’s liquid saliva. Okay? So like you have the liquid tears. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: There’s artificial saliva. So that if this side of your mouth isn’t making the saliva, you can put some of that in, and just moisten it up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because again, you are sort of, your tongue’s sort of moving over, but your brain looks good. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All right. Doctor: But if it gets worse, it don’t make sense, I’d go back to the ER because I don’t know, because that’s what I would say, and it looks like your tongue’s a little bit more trouble getting over, huh, than the last time. Patient: Okay. I mean, these sometime it’s off and on. Sometimes I can you know- Doctor: Well, when you get tired it can do it. Patient: Yeah. So.

Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: I thought Hopkins was doing it. Patient: I don’t know, recall, if it was Hopkins. Doctor: No. It wasn’t. But I can tell you about it. So your color thing said there was nothing. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: From the, the genes that they tested. Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you probably won’t even know what’s going on. Patient: But see doc, say between her and the wife, they’re the ninety percent around me all the time Doctor: Right, right. Patient: -and the reason why I say this. Family Member: I know what to do if you have a seizure because I’ve had a seizure – Patient: And, so, so.. Family Member: - and my aunt has seizures Doctor: Oh. Family Member: And sometimes I have to keep her from swallowing her tongue- Doctor: That’s it. Yeah- Family Member: -by putting the spoon under there, so just letting it flow through. Doctor: -and again point six percent chance is really rare, but it’s probably if I look at all the side effect list it’s the one that would scare me the most if I was reading that form,

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial.

Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me. Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. We would never put you at risk for safety. If let's say you're just sick with something, it's not cancer related. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You don't come down. You got to do this hard thing. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing.

Patient: Thank you. (laughs) Doctor: Um but that’s an option where… Patient: I’m working on year seventy-four so I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Doing pretty darn good. Um but I think the the downside of that trial is you’re here all the time, but the plus side is you’re getting you know the chemo is a standard and the vitamin C we’ll see what happens so. Patient: Yeah. If I need to cancel that trip… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …to S___, it’s a done deal. Doctor: Okay - No. N - honestly you gotta get off Casodex for six weeks anyways… Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: …so the timing is perfect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Why I wanted you in here is one, we have a plan in place…

Family Member: Right. Doctor: And things like that where it looks good in the bottle but there’s no regulation on what’s inside. Remember we talked about how difficult that can be sometimes? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And then I don’t know what’s going to happen if your liver poops out on me then we’re in trouble. Family Member: Right. Because it can affect his liver. Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right? Doctor: Correct Patient: Because you advised no magnesium? Doctor: Well, no. A normal level of magnesium is good. Patient: A normal level Family Member: Like in a multivitamin magnesium? Doctor: Correct. Yes.

Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so the thing that was the nuance when, uh, the nurse called you the other day? Patient: Uh huh? Doctor: Is what we have found is that people who are on the Xtandi or enzalutamide may have a better likelihood of responding to these medicines. Patient: Oh. I see. Doctor: So, where you don’t qualify for this study is you’re not on Xtandi now. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The PSA tells me it’s either this time or three months from now that we’re likely to see a change. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But that’s what we’ve learned about Enzalutamide; don’t give up the ship until it’s clearly different. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because these drugs could be providing a dampening effect Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go.

Patient: Okay, good. Family Member: So how will you know? Doctor: Well I think - Patient: Symptoms. Doctor: - both PSA and scans. We’ll probably plan on doing scans again in three months. Okay. Family Member: His last PSA do you have the results of that? Because we didn’t get uh… Where did you have that done? Doctor: I only have CBC’s from outside, so I think - Patient: I had I had a PSA done. Doctor: - today’s PSA is going to be your one in a long time. Family Member: Okay well he had one… Doctor: Because when they did it in F____ all they did is only blood counts right? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah, B___ City.

Family Member: And, there’s something else? Patient: Is this in my chart? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I just printed it out. Family Member: Uh, yeah. Doctor: It’s in the, um – Family Member: We can have that. Patient: Test results? Doctor: Well, for me, it’s in a tab called “media.” I don’t know what you have access to. Family Member: But it’s the only thing that came up in, in that genetic testing. Doctor: Right. So they, they look at, they look at about thirty genes that are key genes for cancer.

Family Member: They gave me this application to fill out. Doctor: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that. Family Member: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or… Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given - Doctor: Right, no, I agree with you.

FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree. Family Member: But what I appreciate right now is that you’re listening to us. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because even outside of his care, you want to be treated humanely. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member: Or we’ll stay at home and he needs this place. Doctor: I would agree. Who doesn’t need a roof over the heads first of all?

Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: I need to make an appointment with him and do the uh. Doctor: For the scope and all that. Patient: Scope. Doctor: So he makes sure the passage is okay and the bladder is safe and all that. Alright so I’ll let them know if you’re okay with it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor: Yeah I’m gonna tell them so the scheduler will hook you up or J the nurse will talk to the scheduler. Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various Doctor: -things, such as bleeding. Patient: Okay. Should I stop that? Doctor: No. I mean, my sense is you’ve been on it for some reason. I, but, we didn’t start it, right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. My, um, primary doctor did. Doctor: So, you know, that would be the person to check. Patient: Okay. Doctor: with as to sort of, why am I doing this? Patient: Alright. Okay. Doctor: Um. Other questions you guys have? Patient: No. Family Member: The, um, who is the, is it a Hospital B’s, um, clinical trial or is it a combination with another company or? Doctor: Um. So, the phase one

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Of course, I always encourage you guys if it’s available to do the trial because you get a shot at new stuff, you know. I know it’s not a hundred percent shot but it’s better than, it’s not zero so. We’ll talk more Patient: Okay, Alright yeah lets. Doctor: in depth on that. That way you know the schedule, Patient: Right. Doctor: the potential side effects, you know, and you have to decide if it’s worth it for you but I appreciate both of you keeping an open mind which you have done so. Patient: Yes, I have, you know. Doctor: Yes, thank you for that. Patient: You’re the doctor. I’m never gonna deny that. Doctor: Yeah, thank you for coming back and just sort of, you know, they’re like do you want to come, I’m like no, it’s too complicated to have this conversation on the phone. I want them here so we have a plan. Plus, I was a little worried about your pain. Patient: Yeah, okay. I appreciate that. Doctor: Yeah, which is now kind of making me think that maybe, you know, the stuff in the bone is just sort of acting up and has really, we passed the biopsy sort of situation. I mean this should be better. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I can’t talk. Like somebody’s stoppin’ and be talkin’ to me. But, let’s go walk up so ‘cuz I can’t stand up that long. Doctor: I see. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological.

Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg.
