This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem.

Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just….

Patient: Hm, I did not know that. Doctor: Yes and it’s one drug called Taxotere and it’s given through the IV so usually either arm… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …once over one hour every three weeks. Patient: Hm, okay. Doctor: Okay? We do have a study coming up doing that, plus vitamin C high dose. Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I thought you’d like that. Downside if you have to be here all the time. It’s three times a week. Can you imagine vitamin C flitters outta your system. Patient: It does. Doctor: So this is a J___ study that we’re hoping to open within the next… Doctor: …Yeah, probably within the next month. Patient: Neither one of you know what the term ‘really old’ means. Doctor: That’s true. That’s true.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s that simple. I mean when you look across all the thousands of guys with prostate cancer and all the different things out there, the bottom line is don’t get fat. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: And how will you do that? It doesn’t matter. It’s the fact that you don’t. Patient: Right. Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him? Doctor: Sure. I’m a too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I’m an ah aggressive guy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Um you’re a young guy. You don’t want to look back. Or if it was me, Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know (sighs) Patient: Because I don’t mind making a phone call either but probably me stay out or what do you think? Doctor: Yeah it’s gonna be all how we code and get them… Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: So at this point anyway now that we’re in here now okay this is… Doctor: This is it. Family Member: So they’ll approve it probably the next Thursday? Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And then they’ll say oh the note says you’re off study this is standard run of the mill dose of taxo… oh you want to give Neulasta on day two because you’re worried about having compromise of your white cells, which is still a little you know not at the most robust, but your cell lines have- Patient: Sure. Doctor: - gone down because of the previous chemo. But look we have a great respond, so let’s just move on boys and girls. Doctor: And the then they’ll go oh that makes sense Stan and then you show up and then there we are. Patient: Yeah, okay, okay.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, and, let me not forget that you’re also a candidate for a study called, Iron Man. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: Which is an international study where you would there donate once a year a tube of blood, or is it two? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And you fill out questionnaires to share with people about your journey. You know? How is this helping? Not helping? What don’t you like? Family Member: Oh. Doctor: I fill stuff out, too. And then we get all this data together- Family Member: Right. Doctor: - so that people in Brazil and Australia, and, you know, Ireland, all go and answer the same set of questionnaires. So it’s really fascinating because there’s a lot of people like you just all around the world. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Anyway, so, we want you to pony up to that, too. So if that’s not enough to overwhelm you, um, let me know. I can always do more. Patient: Okay. I just need somebody to send me like ah-

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yes. And then, of course, you know, we do do this, and I really want you to consider, you know, donating the extra bloods as we go throughout the year because I get to follow you for this whole time anyways. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So it’s not like you have to come back, and he’s, it’s just when you come back, when we stick you, we can get up to like ten extra tubes of blood because it’s that much we have to check. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Your immune system is really complicated. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we have to check everything. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah. So there’s no sticking or biopsies but it’s a blood draw. And you have lots to spare. So don’t say, “Oh, my, God”. Doctor: “She can take this ten and that’s it. I’m rolling out of here.” No. You have lots, and lots, and lots of blood to donate. Okay? Family Member: Oh, okay.

Patient: Oh no. Doctor: There’s a vacuum devise that we can use Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: and ultimately there’s a penile prosthesis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: That we can give and we have a person here now who specializes in sexual function. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in fact maybe I’ll have him see you. Patient: I do want a relationship with someone Doctor: Okay. Patient: with people you know because I told you what happened with- Doctor: Okay. Okay.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So companies want to make sure that you’re good to go on and they’re not going to get a black eye because there’s something going on that’s not related to what they’re doing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay.

Patient: No. Well, they were having a problem getting my- Doctor: Yes. Exactly. Well, the problem is, it’s just this bad cycle you’re in. You know? Then you’re tired. It comes around and around. Family Member: Yeah just make better choices. Doctor: Okay. Glad we had this conversation about your diabetes in a prostate cancer clinic, but that’s actually number one. Doctor: Plus, you know, you’re getting that stupid, you know, Lupron shot from us, or, all the time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s when you’ll be due. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And look, look I need three still. I need that one, and I needed the one for, from that scooter, and I need Doctor: But, I told you I’m not giving you for the scooter. Patient: I mean, not scooter, I mean the walker. Doctor: For the walker with the seat. Yeah. Okay. Patient: Look, Dr bring in uh, uh, a script, showing that, ‘cuz I lost that when I lost all my ID, sayin’ that I got Doctor: So, you lost the script? Patient: No. The paper that said that I have, no, that you wrote me and said that I have prostate cancer, all Doctor: Okay. You lost that, too? Patient: I’ve been lost that. I’ve been lost that.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah? That was okay? Patient: They put a, they put a little thing in the nose. Doctor: Okay. But I see you don’t need it. So that’s a good sign. Did they give antibiotics while you were there? Patient: Not, not with me. Family Member: Not to take home. Doctor: Not to take home? Okay. Patient: Not to take home. If, if they gave me some, it was in an IV. Doctor: It was in the IV. I think they did. I’m trying to think. I think I talked to the doctor that took care of you – Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: -Uh, because I was like what do you mean he has pneumonia? But that was it. A lot of people got pneumonia this year, unfortunately. Patient: But that had me going.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored.

Patient: …you had another patient that his insurance wouldn’t cover it until… Doctor: It’s the same thing. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Until you actually have a problem and then they go oh look he’s got a problem, okay we’ll give it to you now. I know. Patient: That’s terrible. Doctor: It’s terrible. So… Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation,

Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it? Doctor: V as in Victor. Patient: Oh ARV7 and thought that you know there were some possibilities there. The liver pathology at Hospital B he wasn’t real keen on and so he had the samples sent up here. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: But that had me going. Doctor: Yeah. Did you have the flu? Patient: I think I had both of them. Doctor: You had? Okay? Because when I had talked to them they just thought about the flu for you, and I didn’t get a conformation. So I just need those records from S___’s. We’ll call over. You think he’s back to his old self at this point? Family Member: Not quite. Doctor: Yeah? Almost? Patient: No. Doctor: Is it just the tiredness still not, not great? Patient: Not really a tiredness but balance a little. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: See I told them last I had that, I had that before. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And they gave me, what was it? Potassium.

Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know. Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes.

Patient: for me with cush you see what I’m saying. I got all the controls in everything I do. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I rode it to C___ Doctor: Yeah Patient: , rode it home, no problems, Doctor: Okay. Patient: the mountains the desert everything. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I understand what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah I can only express my concern. Patient: And I got emergency stops that I can hit it… Doctor: Okay. When are you going? Doctor: You want to wait until we know if this medicine does well or you go first and then we start the medicine?

Patient: Much smaller, yeah. Doctor: Draining, or? Patient: Oh, yeah. It’ll drain a little bit, you know, every day. It’s kinda gotten, you can feel it’s a little hard right here, like a hard lump. Doctor: And you’re not on any antibiotics? Patient: No, no. So, they think it’s a combination of the Xgeva and the, uh, oral surgery I had a year ago. Doctor: Anything else going on? Patient: Um, that’s it. Doctor: Uh, last time you talked to C_ about your fatigue at the end of the day. Patient: Eh, just tired at the end, at the end, after working all day. Doctor: Any pain anywhere? Patient: No. Doctor: Any belly pain?

Patient: Who’s Dr. I___? I said that’s not the right- Doctor: Oh, good. They picked the wrong doctor? Because I never got a request that you needed more. Patient: So I said no you have to contact K___ C___. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I gave them all her contact numbers. Doctor: Ohhh. They tried to get a hold of T___. Patient: Yes. Doctor: The nurse practitioner that works with us sometimes. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: But wil see you with W___. That’s what happened. Okay. Wow. Okay. Here’s the question. Do you have the pills now? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. Now you’re good. Alright. Patient: So I did half, (cough)

Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see. Patient: That was what that Radium two point three was - Doctor: Well it did it for quite a while. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Patient: And it worked. I could feel it working. You know I think that was great. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: And that’s what is kind of annoying you know that -

Patient: We did, we did. Doctor: No, no, what did you have today? Yeah. Well, I, I think that’s also part of this is getting me and the radiation folks together ‘cuz I think we’re ordering redundant now. I mean, they ordered a test; I ordered a test. You know, we’re, we need to kind of Patient: Okay. Doctor: Get one test, one doctor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you probably didn’t need to have another PSA test this soon, but we got one. Family Member: Okay. Well that’s fine. Doctor: ‘Cuz in this clinic, (laughs) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It’s automatic. Appointment. PSA. Appointment. So, that’s what they did, too. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Of course. It’s still the same? The PSA. Doctor: So. It’s, it’s not back yet.

Patient: So, I’m not sure that that isn’t a progression of some arthritis. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Could be. Patient: Or something. Healthcare Professional: The bone scan didn’t detect anything new in your hip. Nothing new. Doctor: Right Healthcare Professional: Nothing new. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: I mean, I think the rise is so small. We know it is just starting to breakthrough. Family Member: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: But, probably can’t definitively prove it right now on scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the scans are so nonsensitive. Patient: Okay.

Patient: About this? Doctor: About this and also about the Xtandi itself. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because the the Xtandi will be a part of the treatment anyways. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um so I’m I’m going to go ahead and try to get that one authorized in the meantime. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once once you decide, if you decide to participate in the clinical trial, then you will come back and there will be a screening visit. Or uh we’re going to go through all the eligibility with you. Do a physical exam, go through a CT scan and a bone scan. It’s a little bit more involved. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um if you decide the trial doesn’t sound right for you, then I am going to start the standard Xtandi and we’re going to send it up, send the medication to you house hopefully after its reimbursed. Patient: Right. Patient: No. Uh uh. Oh, you all gon’ call me today or tomorrow about the blood work, right?

Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine. Doctor: Okay. And you’ve been emailing me? Who’s been writing the pain people? Who’s been doing that for you? Patient: What? Doctor: When you need a refill. Patient: Huh, I call R___. Doctor: Okay. But then they need a doctor to sign it. Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need Doctor: That kind of stuff I can help you with uh if you need a refill, um. Patient: Okay. When I take the ibuprofen, then I might only have to take one of the morphine. You know what I’m saying? More during the day, if the pain coming back just take the ibuprofen and I won’t need morphine. (Coughs) Doctor: So I have a known history, and your hepatitis C, they treated it. Right? Patient: No. It’s in, not, huh, you know how you, huh, you go get this medicine for it? They say I’m not in that category to get anything for it. Doctor: Okay. So your, your hepatitis C isn’t serious and hasn’t, huh, caused any-? Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - to go to humans, human trials, but, uh, unless, unless your pain is getting substantially worse, in which case I would strongly encourage you to do the chemo, because that’s going to work the fastest. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now. This, this reminds me of the time when I was in the Marine Corp. The corpsman do the stuff on purpose. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: So it is what it is. But I said that to say the quality of care and the compassion I can see here at J___ H___. I’m not saying it’s not there at K___. There’s some good doctors there, good personnel, that have been very helpful to me. Uh, but, uh, I see it all through the building here when I come here. That’s one thing. I could see it. Doctor: So are we all on the same page now?

Patient: Okay. Um, okay well I follow your advice. Family Member: Can I ask a couple questions? Patient: Yes you can. Family Member: Now I can ask? Patient: Now you can talk. Family Member: So do you have any experience with the BET inhibitor? Have you seen it work or is it so new that you don’t really know? Doctor: I have experience with a different BET inhibitor. So not this particular one. (Coughs) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -was an injection type of BET inhibitor. This one is a pill. So I think uh, no I really don’t have too much experience with this particular one. The study just opened frankly – Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -- and now we have two or three people who will probably start right around the same time. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Right I understand that. Doctor: …we don’t want to make that worse. Okay. Family Member: Mhmm. Patient: Right. Well we looked up the side effects of uh Doctor: Mhmm. The enzalutamide. Yeah. Patient: …uh the enzulamide, whatever. Um there wasn’t anything in there that indicated a kidney uh… Doctor: Right. Patient: Uh (relation) Doctor: So it’s not direct. It would be well I’m super tired or my stomach doesn’t feel good then I eat and drink less. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you’re dehydrated and your - and organ like kidney or liver takes a hit. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Gotcha.

Patient: Yeah. Well, I noticed it hurt, so I tried to take care of it. Iced it and everything else and then about a week later I noticed my leg was swelling and then it moved down my leg into my ankle. Doctor: And you went to the emergency room? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they found it Patient: They all freaked out. Even the doctors, everybody. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life.

Family Member 1: You do nothing. Family Member: You do nothing. They’ll call you. Patient: Oh, you’ll call me? Doctor: I’m not going to call you. The pharmacy will call you. Patient: The pharmacy, right. Family Member: Pharmacy. Right. Patient: And if I don’t hear nothing, then how long, should I call you? Doctor: Give me a week. Just you know, if you use MyChart, you can give us a call. I’ll just follow up with them. They’re usually pretty good about it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s it. Doctor: Other question you guys have? Patient: Do you want me to leave so you can talk?

Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body. Patient: Okay. Doctor: There’s lymph nodes all along there. So at different places uh- Patient: Are there new ones or it’s the same ones that are just enlarged? I mean- Doctor: It looks like the same ones have enlarged a bit. Patient: So what, so what does that tell us? Doctor: Well, it’s confusing because some are actually smaller. Uh up in the chest. So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. And one was uh, uh. That’s actually a little bigger. Uh but the ones in the abdomen and lower down have all gotten bigger. So for the most part by a few millimeters.

Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there. Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Then they, do they attach to the uh to the antibody? Doctor: Well, so it’s not an antibody. Patient: Oh. Its an enzyme, enzyme.. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And if it’s time we do it. You know? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I need to be assured as you guys do also. Family Member: Right. Doctor: That there’s nothing new or that these guys all of a sudden didn’t wake up and go, yeah, well, we were sleeping. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All those lymph nodes and now we’re awake. And we would know if we’re awake because it would be bigger or if it was new. Like, wait a minute.

Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. It just takes me forever to- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -get to sleep. Doctor: When was the last time you took that medication? Patient: The Erlida?

Family Member: Can I just inject on the Cornell thing? Clinical trials seem to me like they are very regimen and very time consuming, and I don’t think your situation gives you that. I just don’t want to waste your Doctor: Well, you know, if it’s the same drug, which it is, and it’s you know and- Patient: And it’s available. Family Member: No. But I’m just very uh the anxiety of the whole thing is, is he - Doctor: I mean the Cornell group has a lot of experience giving you know radioactive compounds, just not for this one, because they’re just starting to do it, so they’ve probably treated a thousand people, maybe they treated three or four hundred people. No wonder that matters. It’s just giving somebody radioactive stuff and making sure after that happens part of it does that big of a difference, uh? Patient: Yeah. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that- Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I think that’s fair. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I think that’s reasonable. It reasonable. Doctor: Are you just agreeing with me to agree with me? Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay?

Patient: Right. Doctor: that’s just too time consuming especially based on where you guys live and so on. So, there is a liquid radiation that’s available for patients who have, Healthcare Professional: No its okay, I decided to come on in here. Doctor: and they do that six months so once a month for six months and that’s been shown to help people live longer and that’s actually FDA approved. So, one could run that through the insurance, you know get treated, and be on your way. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Yeah. What’s new? Patient: Nothing. Doctor: Nothing. Is this one giving you trouble? Doctor: She gives me trouble. I’m glad you qualified. We’re just waiting on the paperwork. patients. Family Member: You can talk. I’m just talking with a patient. Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study.

Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time- Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I thought that was concentrating on that bundle that was in the lumbar region. Doctor: Yep. It was. Patient: It wasn’t, it wasn’t throughout where I have cancer throughout the spine. Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Patient: That’s good. That’s good. I’m going to keep the faith that everything is, is good. Doctor: Okay. Now very good. (pause7sec) Patient: I try not to worry. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Don’t worry. Patient: Worry. You know? Because that, that’s, that’s bad. Doctor: That’s very bad. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yes. You don’t want to do that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stress can cause a lot of problems with the rest, other parts of the body.

Patient: Right. Doctor: that much of a difference. So… Family Member: Is that the only lymph node involved? Doctor: That’s visible right now. Family Member: Oh, okay. So that’s the same one that’s been there? Doctor: Previously, before we started, I think there were more than one that we were seeing. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Before we started on the Xtandi and everything, you know the study. But since then we really barely even see those lymph nodes and even so they’ve been so small. Family Member: Great. Patient: So does that indicate that what your husband did worked? Family Member: Well no, that’s the bone scan. Doctor: No it doesn’t.

Family Member: Ahhhh. Doctor: We can get a PSA. If that PSA is higher than what we have, then R_ will sort of talk to you about coming back down to get some of this other stuff. So, we’ll be watching you behind the scenes – Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: To sort of figure out when’s the right time for you to come back. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Got it. Patient: So, the first thing is to, uh, see if I can come up (healthy) Doctor: Yeah. Just to see, yeah, how much it’s gonna cost ya. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Patient: I think last time I was on the Xtandi, they wanted to know if I have any income to speak of or – Doctor: Yeah. They’ll do the wallet check and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If they think you make enough money that you should be able to pay for it, then they’re not gonna give you one of these, uh, uh, grants.

Patient: Would I continue on the Xtandi in that case or not? Family Member: Okay but she said there’s a third choice. Patient: Just a second, just a second, just a second I’m digesting this. Family Member: Sorry. Patient: Thank you. Ah… Doctor: I know it’s a lot of things to go through. Patient: anyway so so, with that one I continue on the Xtandi with uh, um… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That’s not the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: Correct. And both medications would be provided by the study. Patient: I don’t know if my insurance would cover the Xtandi and the Xtandi is ten thousand dollars a month. Doctor: Yeah so I think chances are you insurance will cover it. Okay?

Patient: This is experimental? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Patient: And uh so I would take the BET1 inhibitor and keep on the Xtandi? Doctor: That’s correct. Patient: And the Lupron? Doctor: So that’s an option. Okay? The other option is do we go now to the medications based on your BRCA mutation should we start you on Lynparza which is one of the medications that are basically given for BRCA mutation patients with prostate cancer. Okay. Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is --

Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Family Member: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month? Doctor: No. Family Member: Oh good. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh!

Patient: Okay, Alright Doctor: It really is and whether we pick chemo as the next step and sort of, you know, we say kind of learn out way through it, it will depend on how we fare. Hi, J____. What’s happening. Patient: Hi. Healthcare Professional: I know you wanted me to try to get the CT Doctor: Oh Healthcare Professional: and the report right now so I’m just gonna Doctor: Oh like for July? Healthcare Professional: Yes. So, if you can sign and date, I’m sorry to interrupt you, Doctor: No, no no Healthcare Professional: but I figured if I can get it while… Doctor: J____ is like Speedy Gonzales. She’s like let’s roll, let’s roll. Healthcare Professional: It’s really so I don’t forget it later.

Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. Family Member 1: When will you know that? Doctor: Yeah, so this is where it gets complicated. I'm gonna have my research nurse M_____ come in, it's always the devils in the details. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: What's tight about this and what's goofy about it and we've already shared this with a company is that they almost want to be like, okay, we know everything about you. And then two weeks later, you have to start. So there's a time thing that's so compressed, that I even fear that you might even, you know, need another CAT scan, because they only want everything done in a two week window. So if that's the case, obviously, she'll time it out. But I defer to the research team to make sure that that's done correctly. And I've learned over the years to basically zip it because I say something they're like, “Yeah, no, you just botched up that schedule.” So I just stay out of it and let Melanie take over. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yes. Right. Doctor: all guys that are getting older are at risk for a hernia so don’t do that. Patient: I won’t. I won’t do that no more. Doctor: Okay and when you go home please take the Norco. Patient: I will. I like what you said on this. I definitely want it at night. That’s I’m not gonna miss that one. Doctor: Then you’re gonna rest. Patient: Yes and I like that. During the day see what. Doctor: Yeah, you just see how it, and then, you know, when you take this don’t drive, Patient: Right. Right Doctor: don’t do, I mean and literally don’t drive heavy machinery. Patient: Yeah, I don’t. Doctor: The number of times I’ve had to say that. Wait, so I can’t go out there and work on the tractor? Patient: Right. No.

Patient: Oh man, come on listen you gotta understand something doc, you got to be able to share the wealth and be a cheerful giver. DOC; Mm, hmm. Doctor: Yeah, we’re gonna definitely go over the results don’t you worry. Patient: Yeah. yeah. Doctor: They’re the spots in the back. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It still is that one area. Patient: It, it it ain’t moved at all? Doctor: No. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: I’m very glad just like W___ that it’s not in your hip. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: You already say Dr. P___ a while ago do you remember that for your back. Patient: Yes. Yes.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And as we discussed before, this is generally considered a little bit controversial. It’s not the standard therapy. So if you read a textbook about managing advanced prostate cancer it would only say that you’d give Abiraterone you’d also give an injectable suppression at the same time like Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: However, as I told you before, I have used Abiraterone (Zytiga) Patient: Yes, I have also, and I think I was zero point something for over a year. Doctor: Yeah, about point one. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yes, so again, with the caveat that it would be considered unconventional therapy – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - you know given that caveat if we both acknowledge that, I would be willing to consider that for you, especially if the studies don’t show any disease or metastatic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: disease is one. And if we were both informed that this is really not the conventional therapy and yet you still want to or agree to do it. But I think as long as it’s an informed decision, I’m willing to consider that.

Patient: That’s him. Doctor: We got him here. Patient: Oh he’s here now. Doctor: He’s here now. So he’s the go-to guy to get that process through. It goes through his group. Okay? So my suggestion is that we just have a discussion with him about side effects and pros and cons and what not as the next step. In the meantime you’re taking more pain medicine, right? Regularly. Family Member: I can’t – he’s like a little child “time for your medicine, are you going to take it?” Doctor: I know. Patient: Well I mean is there a benefit to taking the pain medication? Doctor: Yeah, you’d be more functional. Patient: Well I’m functionable. Family Member: But you’re in pain. Patient: Well then I also feel that if I’m masking the pain too much, then I’m overextending myself. Or maybe I shouldn’t be. Doctor: Oh well, set your activity level and don’t exceed it.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So I don’t really know where you’re at but I think I’m hearing that you may be interested in thinking about this radiation option first? Patient: Well as a Patient, you have a person that quote/unquote “has the cancer”. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: My primary objective would be to get rid of it. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: So if that’s not possible through the methods that you have, then what I need to look at uh is what can you offer us as far as a method of treatment um to kind of you know work on this targeted area – Doctor: Um hum. Patient: - you know still thinking that I mean you know it’s not to say this is the only place it’s going to develop. Doctor: Right. Patient: I mean you could target this - Doctor: Right.

Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years.

Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know. Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something.

Patient: Start chemo or… Doctor: Yes xxx]. Patient: They don’t do um radiation to the lymph nodes. Doctor: They could, but you know the problem is… Patient: It spreads. Doctor: xxx] right. Yeah. Yeah, it’s not one lymph node that’s remaining. Patient: Right. Doctor: I would rather do the chemotherapy to get things in check, then if there’s one or two resistant spots to the SBRT you know the very closely blind radiation to that. Patient: Right. Family Member: So is there a specific chemotherapy that you would use or do you have an option for… Doctor: No I think then you can get it xxx]. Patient: xxx]. Doctor: Yeah I wouldn’t do it, I would just call Dr. C___.

Patient: Yeah… Doctor: And it can help with any reactions that uh from the chemo too. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So okay. (whispering inaudibly to herself) Patient: No. Doctor: I’ll send it right here? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, cool. Alright so next time I see you will be on the twenty eighth. His PSA wasn’t bad was it? Healthcare Professional: Down, down from so… Doctor: Just slightly down. Healthcare Professional: So slightly down. Doctor: Okay, it’s heading in the right direction. Patient: Oh, okay.

Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Hopefully, it hasn’t changed in two weeks. Doctor: Your sugars are high, though. Are you on – remind me, Are you diabetic? I can’t remember. Patient: Yeah. I have type two diabetes. Doctor: So, your sugar was high today. Three hundred. You probably didn’t fast. Family Member: No, he didn’t fast. Patient: No, I didn’t. Family Member: He had a donut. Doctor: Yeah, there you go. Patient: It was really good. Doctor: Good.

Family Member: Alright. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Thank you for your time! Patient: Thanks for your time! Doctor: Good to see you. Huh? Family Member: Good to see you. Other than that, Doctor: Yeah. I think she’s got a questionnaire or two for you. Okay. I’ll let A_ know. Patient: Now, you’re gonna, now they’re gonna check the pharmacy and let me know? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I have to – I give it to our pharmacist, and then she’ll start processing it. Patient: Okay.

Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time. Doctor: Yeah and by then we’ll know what trial makes sense um to offer… Patient: You know I do see on the internet, I think it was a… Doctor: Yeah Patient: British article about immunotherapy with prostate cancer… Doctor: Mhmm, Yes. Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA?

Family Member: I’m off that Friday anyway so that works fine. Doctor: You’re sure? You have nothing planned yet? (laughs) Family Member: Um, working on the house. Patient: She’s off all week. I forgot about that. So that will work. Family Member: I’ve got all kinds of house repairs, painting and odds and ends things to do around the house. So I just took some vacation time to do that. Doctor: Wow. Family Member: Not exactly what you want to do on vacation… Doctor: I know. That’s exactly right. I do it too. It needs to be done. I know. We all laugh at those. (Laughs) Family Member: It’s so hard. Doctor: I can think of a few closets of mine that I’ve been trying to ignore but then after a while it gets too much. (Laughs) Family Member: Oh I wish it was just closets. Doctor: Oh, it’s a lot more? Family Member: Oh yeah.

Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too. Doctor: Yeah. If he had to. Family Member: But it’s hard to get. Doctor: But for now let’s keep it. Family Member: That’s what I think. We’ve waited a long time. Doctor: Don’t, don’t change anything until we see what the dates fall out to be. Family Member: Fine. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Family Member: But it’s an indication of prostate cancer, and as far as we know, that’s all that he has. Doctor: Right. Right. Family Member: Even though, it’s in different places. Doctor: Right. And, sometimes when the PSA goes up, the scans can still look stable, because they’re not as sensitive to changes as the, as the – Patient: As the chemical – Doctor: Blood count. Yeah. Patient: Okay. So, the bloodwork I did today. What was that for? Doctor: That was for me to feel good about myself. No, uh. That was mostly looking at PSA. Patient: Again? Doctor: I think that – That was today’s blood. So. Family Member: So, they had a PSA. Patient: We did, we did.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did. Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right.

Family Member: And then if you didn’t see results, would you go to a bone marrow? Patient: Right. Doctor: Well, we could do chemotherapy still. We could do a trial of chemotherapy. Uh you know the bone marrow transplant to me, you know, it’s a trial that I’m doing. You know it’s the only treatment I know of that cures cancer. So if you take people with bad leukemia and bad lymphoma you can cure them- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: by giving them somebody else’s immune system. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But I haven’t, I don’t cure anybody with prostate cancer, so I’m getting frustrated in my career. You know? Is there something I can do that has a chance to cure the disease? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The only thing I could think of, so we’re testing the bone marrow transplant idea is being prostate. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So their immune system has not been exposed to prostate tissue. What if we used a female into a male? Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay! Doctor: And then when you’re done, they say, “Wake up, Mr. L_! You’re goin’ home!” Patient: I’m goin’ home. Doctor: And she’s gonna bring you home! And that’s the end! It’s all outpatient. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: I’m not gonna be there. Patient: Okay. So, doc. So, doc. So, doc. Doctor: I’m going to go get M_. Patient: Okay, doc. So, so, okay. Doctor: Okay! Patient: So – Healthcare Professional 1: I just want to ask him, Effexor – Doctor: Oh, yeah!

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll request, I don't know if its available, but I hope it is; if it’s eight a.m., it will be earlier. Patient: That will be fine. Doctor: So that will be for the appointment itself. So we’ll sign that. And then the next step will be to order the PSA and the testosterone the week before Patient: Could you also include the um, my diabetes AC. Doctor: The A1C. Patient: Yes, A1C and I could just give them to my doctor. Doctor: Okay, so a week before would be the week of January eighth. I’m just going to click on that day and I’ll click on the boxes approximate, so it will be any day of the week of January eighth – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - and then I’ll click on LabCorp. Patient: Uh hum, can you do multiple orders or do just have to be one order. Doctor: Each one is separate, so you can have three different pieces of paper printed out. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Yeah, okay, okay. Doctor: So I think we should just reschedule for next Thursday, the shot on Friday and that’s that. Patient: Okay, okay. Reschedule what for next Thursday? Family Member: Chemo. Doctor: Chemo. Patient: Oh and then have that follow-up shot on Friday? Doctor: Correct. Patient: Okay. Um a couple quick questions though. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You’ve still got time? Doctor: Yeah shoot. Patient: Okay um are they not coming in to video tape? Doctor: They are. They’re videoing right now. Say hi! Wave it will go up and down. They see us.

Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know, I’m sorry. Patient: And you would recommend that at least at a minimum? Doctor: Well, you know there’s two ways to approach this. We could wait until you really are in trouble. And in trouble would mean you have a fever, you have no white cells, you better come in to the hospital, you need antibiotics. Patient: Yeah I don’t know (stammering) Doctor: But you’ve already demonstrated that your cells go down. You know you weren’t doing great. I just think we’re asking for trouble. So I’ve tried to explain that and they’re like is it a fever with no white cells. That’s all the understand. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: B_, P_. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And, uh, so we’re, we’re always thinking that J__ health issues could be genetically related because they’re very, they’re actually very complex. And, uh, anyway. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Well, I just did a literature search. There’s one thousand five hundred and fifty papers MTHFR cancer. So, you’ll have a lot to read. (Laughs) Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Well, I would – Family Member: And, APS, too, a blood thing, I’m gonna bet that’s probably all – Patient: Okay. Family Member: Wait. Are we supposed to do that film thing or did we do it already. Doctor: I think we’re doing it. Family Member: Oh, we’re doing it. Doctor: I know, and we’re done! And I --

Patient: Okay. Doctor: That might take a minute. Patient: Okay. Family Member: In addition to the radium or that? Doctor: No, that is the radium. Patient: Oh, that is the radium. Doctor: Yeah. So, there’s different names. Family Member: Oh, I got you. Doctor: Radium, there’s liquid radiation, there’s Xofigo, which is the trade name, and, you know, we don’t give it but the radiation oncology doctors give it because it is a form of radiation. So, they’ll go over everything but what I would do is we would start the prior authorization process with our insurance but you then would talk to the radiation oncology doctor for a formal consultation and then they go over the pros and cons of what’s gonna happen and so on and so on. Patient: You know about it I’m sure about this. You know about the radiation that I had Doctor: Uh huh. Yep Patient: and is it similar to that or is the… Doctor: Different.

Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. It is one injection and then watch it? Doctor: Uh usually it’s, it’s IV, it’s every three weeks for as far as it works. So it could be you know- Patient: A year? Doctor: I don’t know what that all costs, but uh- Family Member: But do you know right away after one or two? Doctor: I would say probably after two or three you’d know if it’s working. Family Member: By that time, would we be able to go to Germany within a month? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: All we’ve got is a maybe. Family Member: Can’t be sure?

Patient: I don’t think that did anything for me. Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah. Patient: And so after a couple of months, he said, “This isn’t working,- Doctor: Yes. Patient: -so let’s not continue it.” Doctor: Right. You know the good part is there’s always new stuff coming down the pike. Patient: There is. Doctor: And we’ve just got to keep you upright and functioning and enjoying life- Patient: Right Doctor: -and keep those options open. Patient: But the other thing, I mean this is kind of the other side of what you have to deal with- Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: In group one. Doctor: I don’t know if it’s group one; I heard group two. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Um. And then once those three have been treated, then, they’ll open up again for three more people. Patient: Okay. How often do you do that? Doctor: Uh, you have to be on drug for at least about, the third person should be on at least a month, and it all has to be deemed safe, and then the next three people. Patient: Oh, okay. Alright. Family Member: If it is, they take it to next level. Doctor: So, again, theoretically, if you stayed on treatment and then three months from now, he clearly showed a progression of disease then, there might be a window when the slot would be available. Patient: Okay. So, if I stay on this for three months, it’s most likely that, uh, let’s say it’s group two (for sake of argument) Doctor: Correct. For the current cohort, uh, oh, one slot left. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.
